Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2013 11:37AM ndgirl wrote: Hang in there Sophia! getting news that wasnt totally expected is not the way you want your day to go, but it will probably be the same treatments anyway, they told me at Mayo that the final pathology is after surgery, the frozen section they do immediately is usually right but not always.  I know it is so hard to do but try not to panic, once you get your plan of action in gear you will feel better. I had a very hard time deciding between mx and lumpectomy but finally chose mx, just to ease my mind that hopefully all cells would be gone with the boob.. we never know tho but we never have any guarantees in anything.. sending big hugs to you!!! these boards are wonderful for everything, we can vent when we are angry, share when excited or happy and share our feeling, hopes everything here. It has been such a tremenous help for me, a good therapy! Take big deep breaths, hold for a few seconds and blow out slowly thru your mouth, it does help relieve stress! Stay positive but you dont always have to be strong either, have a good cry when you need it, but dont let it be the thing you always want to do. We are all here for you!  Love from Linda
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 02:49PM ndgirl wrote: Barbie, no I did not have cancer 20 years ago but that is what the pathologists said, and I was actually set for surgery, long story short, we had a  trip already planned to our son's in Houston, and he is insisted that I come there for another opinion, and I also had another in the largest city in ND, and they said it was dcis, went to MD Anderson and they said it was not cancer! a begnien breast disease, I realize that they see alot more breast tissue in MD than in North Dakota but I wrote them saying they needed to send slides on to a major breast center if it was a gray area. The other breast now gave me the trouble. Always be your own advocate and ask lots of ????
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 08:55PM ndgirl wrote: Wow Sophia, that is great, I have not heard of meeting with pathologist, but great idea as I was misdiagnosed 20 years ago, I would still like to meet with that pathologist, I did end up with bc but it was in the other breast that they diagnosed! Best of luck to you. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2013 08:49PM ndgirl wrote: gtgirl, I had the shots in breast before surgery, and really they were not that bad at all, just little stings. They explained what was happening and why, told me some ladies find them painful but most dont and I sure did not enjoy it, but was nothing I have bad memories of, just a few stings. Ask for the numbing cream, it helps, but I hope you dont worry too much about these, they do not last long either. Good luck. keep us posted!
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 07:08AM ndgirl wrote: Yes, no cure, guess we all know that, but agree that we dont have to die from it either, my son has had diabetes type 1 since he was 12 and will be 40 this year, no cure for that disease either but he manages it quite well, of course there has been and will be bumps in the road to get over but guess we all have a path in life and now this darn cancer is ours. There is a radiation called "proton therapy" that is available in only a few places in us, Mayo will start it next year, think MD Anderson has it now. It is used in Germany and European countries now, we know a young man that is involved with the process and is really singing the praises, it is meant to target areas and not damage other tissues as much, I asked about it at Mayo and they seem very optimistic but at this time insurance wouldnt cover me for it.. hopefully more will be discovered shortly. I have my 4 month checkup on Wed. and I am getting nervous about it, just going to the onocology floor, havent quite wrapped my head around all this yet!  Barbie.. agreed.. well said!
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2013 03:50AM ndgirl wrote: I had a mastectomy at 7 am and they said i could go home that night if I wanted, but I chose to spend one night in hospital as I am a long distance from hospital/doctor. I really did fine, but I had never had any kind of surgery before and dealing with tubes scared me but they were not that bad either. Good positive thoughts going your way.
Posts.Title: lumpectomy, home same day? vaper Moderators

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 12:09AM ndgirl wrote: welcom NLM, these are great boards to help us through everything facing us. I started arimidex the first of May, I cant begin to tell you how scared and worried I was about taking this.. but so far not too bad. No side effects at first but the last 2 weeks I think the fatique has set in, not every day but when it hits it hits hard, just knocks me down for the whole day! But I also tend to overdue, I just go too much and hard and guess my body tells me to slow up, am hoping this doesnt last. But  5 years taking a drug is a long time and sure hope it does what they say it will. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2013 11:30AM ndgirl wrote: Great post mdphil, that is just what we all need, a good dose of encouragement! Lighthouselady, I hear you on not sleeping, I just dont sleep well, i have my 4 month checkup August 21 and am going to talk to dr. about something, I have never before taken any prescription meds so am scared of alot but have to do it now, arimidex for 5 years, now hopefully something to sleep a little anyway, insominia is terrible. I used to be saying my nightly prayers and fall asleep, then feel guilty about not finishing them, but now that doesnt even work,  Hang in there, we are all here for you. Linda
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - tired of crying, ready to get on with it! lighthouselady bcisnofun

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 01:27PM ndgirl wrote: Pelively, is it soft and moveable? I had one that was called a gangeline sp?? cysty, fluid filled sac, dr. drained it and it came back, eventually went away. But with out situations I believe everything should be checked out, we dont need more worry than we already have and everything that is put to rest is a big plus! Good luck.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2013 12:00PM ndgirl wrote: Thinking of you luke... Christmas is the season of miracles so praying your spots are not what you are thinking. We never know with this crap do we? I am your age and like you when I see the young women with young families my heart aches for them. I did chose to have mx, dr. said chemo wasnt necessary but I am taking arimidex as cancer was hormone positive. We have to be content with the decision we made at the times and we felt we were dong what was best then. Good luck with appt. and keep us updated on results.. we are all here for you!! Always remember that.
